pr_title: PLANNER-2093 Schema Definition for SolverConfig and BenchmarkConfig

timeline.message: Resolve conflicts after rebase to master
Make naming of JAXB adapters consistent
Move JAXB adapters to a subpackage
Simplify comparison of xml content in tests

timeline.bodyText: As we agreed, we don't validate the input solver config XML. We use the validation just in tests to make sure the solver config XML is valid by the generated XSD.
timeline.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText:
soft: I think putting error messages in a constant - if it's only used once - is a form of unneeded indirection, making the code harder to read (code is read 10 times more than it it written) because it reduces "vertical density" (that which belongs together is together).
In this case, the ERR_MSG_READ is used more than once, but that's often a sign that multiple different error causes are being reported as the same error, providing less information to the user. See examples below.
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
These error message formatting are not consistent with our normal formatting "... parameterName (parameterValue) ..."
So
"Unable to write the %s to XML."
=> "Unable to write rootClass (%s) to XML."
replies.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
A rootClass isn't written to XML, it's marshalled to XML.
We typically favor "Failed to" instead of "Unable to".
=> "Failed to marshall rootClass (%s) to XML."
replies.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
Only messages that repeat are defined as constants. However, I changed the message in a couple of places to make it more specific.
Thanks.
replies.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText: DRY with the first few lines of write(T root, Writer writer).
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

timeline.bodyText: The errorMessage String should only be created if it actually fails, so inside the catch
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

timeline.bodyText:
Here, it didn't fail to marshall the rootClass to XML, so the error message should be different.
=> "Failed to format XML for rootClass(...)." maybe?
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

timeline.bodyText:
Do we need to bring in an XSLT formatter to format the JAXB output?
Can we not use this instead?
marshaller.setProperty(Marshaller.JAXB_FORMATTED_OUTPUT, Boolean.TRUE);
Less XSLT is always better ;-)
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
Unfortunately, the Marshaller.JAXB_FORMATTED_OUTPUT does always 4 spaces of indentation. We use the XSLT to make it 2 (or any other number, if needed).
For the "backward compatibility mode", when writing the elements, we remove their namespaces via an XSLT, so we need a transformation anyway.
replies.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText:
error style, always use braces to mention values at runtime.
=> "... rootClass (%s) ... namespaces (%s)."
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

timeline.bodyText:
Do we need a custom class for this?
We can probably just do
String s = validationEventCollector.getEvents().stream().map(Event::getMessage).collect(Collectors.joining("\n"))
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

timeline.bodyText: open question (maybe for another PR): Is this public API? Should SolverFactory.createFromXmlResource()'s javadoc have a "@throws OptaPlannerXmlSerializationException" ? In that case we might want to move it into the api package.
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText:
Naming:

We avoid class names that contain the word "OptaPlanner" because everything in our repository is about OptaPlanner.
Is it Serialization or Marshalling? Much of the other code naming and error messages seem to talk about marshalling, not serialization. Let's use one term and stick with that.
replies.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText: The same question applies to all the fail-fast checks: should we mention there the IllegalArgumentException? Maybe it should. In that case, I would definitely do it in a separate PR.
replies.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText:
Naming consistency: the only implementation of an interface Foo is normally called DefaultFoo in the rest of the optaplanner repo. This makes it easier to guess when doing ctrl-n.
=> rename GenericJaxbIO to DefaultJaxbIO
timeline.author: ge0ffrey

replies.bodyText: It's not the only implementation; it's just the only one that takes a generic type parameter. Other implementations deal e.g. with the SolverConfig and use this generic one under the hood.
replies.author: rsynek

timeline.bodyText: Read didn't fail here. Validation failed. Or if read includes validation, then actually stating "validation failed" is more specific. The error message should reflect that, so users don't think that the file wasn't found.
timeline.author: ge0ffrey
